results.title: Mindfulness of Body

results.title: Mindfulness of Breath
results.description: Mindfulness while breathing in and out is a practical application of right mindfulness, the seventh factor of the Noble Eightfold Path. This topic encompasses both the step-by-step training process an
synonyms: mindfulness while breathing in and out

results.title: Mindfulness
results.description: Remembering to be present with continuous effort, observing the body, feelings, mind, and mental qualities in and of themselves.

results.title: Sati sutta - Mindfulness
results.description: The Buddha explains how a bhikkhu should live with mindfulness and full awareness.

results.title: Recollection of death
results.description: Keeping in view the certainty and nearness of death. Recollection of death ignites wholesome desire for awakening and sustains uphill vigour against habitual tendencies.

results.title: Recollection of the Buddha
results.description: A mental quality of reflecting on the qualities of the Buddha, which counters doubt and strengthens faith.
synonyms: reflection on the qualities of the Buddha

results.title: Recollection of the Dhamma
results.description: A mental quality of reflecting on the qualities of the Dhamma, which counters doubt and strengthens faith.
synonyms: reflection on the qualities of the Dhamma

results.title: Recollection of the Sangha
results.description: A mental quality of reflecting on the qualities of the Saṅgha, which counters doubt and strengthens faith.
synonyms: reflection on the qualities of the Saṅgha

results.title: Wrong mindfulness
results.description: Remembering in the wrong way. It holds to the signs of craving and aversion, or attends carefully to what sustains delusion. Such mindfulness appears clear but lacks right view, turning awareness into

results.title: Laṭukikopama sutta - Simile of the Quail

results.title: Biḷāra sutta - Cat
results.description: The Buddha uses a simile of a cat and a mouse to illustrate how not setting up mindfulness and being unrestrained in the sense faculties can lead to death or deadly suffering.

results.title: Makkaṭa sutta - Monkey
results.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a monkey caught in a sticky trap to illustrate the dangers of wandering in unsuitable places and the importance of mindfulness.
